content.question:
<math alttext="H F aqueous plus H 2 O liquid is in equilibrium with H 3 O with a positive 1 charge aqueous plus F with a negative 1 charge aqueous " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O(</mtext><mi>l</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
The equation above represents the acid ionization equilibrium for <math alttext="H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. To prepare a buffer with <math alttext="p H is approximately equal to 3.50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext><mo>≈</mo><mn>3.50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="4.20 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a F solid " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> should be added to <math alttext="500.0 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.100 molar H F aqueous " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HF(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The buffer is accidentally prepared using 90% pure <math alttext="N a F solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> instead of 99% pure <math alttext="N a F solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. Assume that the impurities in the <math alttext="N a F solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>F</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> samples are inert. Which of the following explains how the error affects the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and capacity of the buffer?

choices.label: The <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is slightly higher than 3.50 and it has a lower capacity for the addition of acids because less than <math alttext="4.20 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a F solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was added.

The <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is slightly higher than 3.50 and it has a higher capacity for the addition of acids because more than <math alttext="4.20 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a F solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was added.

The <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is slightly lower than 3.50 and it has a lower capacity for the addition of acids because less than <math alttext="4.20 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a F solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was added.

The <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is slightly lower than 3.50 and it has a higher capacity for the addition of acids because more than <math alttext="4.20 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a F solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was added.

content.answer: The <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is slightly lower than 3.50 and it has a lower capacity for the addition of acids because less than <math alttext="4.20 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a F solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was added.

skill.text: 6.G: Explain how potential sources of experimental error may affect the experimental results.
